subject: thoughts to live by
verse: I will forgive their wickedness and will remember their sins no more. (Jer. 31:34)
reflection: What can you do with that water stain on the ceiling? Try covering it with ordinary paint, but it still bleeds through. Buy the special paint made to cover such stains, but you still see its faint outline each time you look at the ceiling. Don't we sometimes act as if God deals the same way with our sins? Don't we sometimes act as if Jesus merely covered them over and yet they're still there? Why? Didn't you notice what the gracious Lord said? He does more than cover our sins ~ He removes them. He doesn't even remember our sins. Our sins are gone as if they never existed. All because He sent His Son to pay for them on Calvary's cross. Thank God we don't have to enter the new year with the stains of last year's sins upon us. They're totally gone ~ blotted out completely by the precious blood of the Savior. Oh yes there will be sins in this new year too ~ there will be plenty of them. Old familiar ones that we fight against and yet fall back into. New ones that we stumble into because they sneak up on us. What shall we do, what can we do, with all their wretched stains? The same thing we did last year. Bring them with tears of repentance to God, and thank Him each day of this new year for forgiving our sins and remembering them no more.
prayer: Thank You, Lord, for Your forgiveness that remains new for us each day. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: The Lord gives His people strength. The Lord blesses them with peace. (Ps. 29:11)
reflection: How many of us know about threats and stress? How many of us have carried burdens from the old year into the new? How many of us have found that these burdens seem to pick up more weight day by day? And who knows what new problems will drop down on our shoulders tomorrow? What's the solution? Where can we find release from our fears and relaxation under our burdens? There's only one place ~ one person ~ the Lord. He who prepared in Jesus the perfect peace we need for our souls will also provide what we need for our daily lives. With our eyes on such a loving Lord, we can go forward even though the steps are painful. We can smile even in the midst of tears. If with hearts of faith, we lay our burdens before God, the result will always be peace.
prayer: Dear Lord, Help me to fasten my heart on Your gracious promise and fill my life with Your peace. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Be strong in the Lord and His mighty power. (Eph. 6:10)
reflection: Those rust nails wouldn't budge. I finally, reach for my 'power bar, ' which has a much longer handle. The nails finally let go and one by one came out of the board. My 'power bar' gave me the extra power I needed. None of us are strangers to temptation. Each of us has his own area of weakness that the sly devil explores and the sinful world exploits. And the evil hearts within us never sleep or give up the struggle. You know what I'm talking about??? How long would the list be if we were to catalog the soft spots where temptations sink in so easily? ~ How many times have we been pinned to the mat of sin by the old evil foe instead of winning the match??? Will it get any better this new year? Will our struggle against sin be more successful? Not if we use only the puny hammer of our own efforts. More power is needed. And the Lord Jesus offers us that added power. "[He] appeared. to destroy the devils work" Scripture tells us. (1 Jn. 3:8) Not only has God's Son paid for our sins, but He has also broken Satan's stranglehold on us. When Satan is successful in our lives, it's not because Christ's power has failed. BUT it is because our hold on His 'power bar' isn't as firm as it should be.
prayer: Dear Lord, tighten my grip on Your Word through which You give my faith Your mighty power. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: We saw His star in the east and have come to worship Him. (Mt. 2:2)
reflection: We don't know much about the Magi. Scripture doesn't reveal what country they came from, how many there were, what occupations or names they had. What we need to know about them, though, the biblical account has recorded. They were led by some mysterious star ~ "His" star ~ right to Jesus' side. and when the Magi saw their infant Savior, they knew what to do. They knelt down and worshiped Him. The Magi were the first in a long line of Gentiles brought to the Savior, a line that by God's grace includes us also. They were led by a star. Our star is even better."You word is a lamp to my feet and a light for my path, " the psalmist wrote (119:105), and we would heartily agree."We have seen His star, " we say with the Magi, not in the east, but, better still, in His Word. Now the Lord has given us a new year in which to be guided by His Word to the Savior. Modern Magi know where their eyes belong ~ on God's wondrous star.
prayer: Dear Lord, help us to live in Your Holy Word, and to see our Savior there. Amen.

reflection: Some people like snow, at least the first snow of the winter. The beautiful white flakes cover earth's dead vegetation and everything looks so pure. How could we get up and start another day without the promise of His forgiveness? ~ How could we go to bed each night without the assurance, "Were as scarlet my transgression, it shall be as white as snow by Your blood and bitter passion" (Christian Worship 304:6)? prayer: Cover me, Lord, with Your Son's forgiveness that I might be pure in Your sight. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: He sends the snow like white wool. (Ps. 147:16a)
reflection: It goes without saying that the psalmist knew who made it snow ~ so do we. When the road home from work is snow covered and slippery, the driveway plugged by the passing snowplow, the side walk almost buried under the drifting snow, do we stop to think who sent the it??? If we have to start the snowblower and do the shoveling we're not to tickled. Next time it snows, stop for a moment and consider the hand behind it. Remember its the hand of our almighty God. ~ He alone fills the clouds with moisture ~ forms the snow flakes ~ and sends them fluttering down. It's our all-knowing God who waters the fields ~ fills the reservoirs ~ and provides for His creatures. His divine hand sends not only the snow but everything else good for His children. Yes from this divine weatherman we look for weather that is always ~ "fair." But remember for the flowers we appreciate so much there must also be rain. Difficulties strengthen our faith as labor does the body.
prayer: Dear Lord, help me to see your hand at work in the changing seasons of my life, help me to appreciate the fact that if it was always fair, my faith would not be as strong as it is. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: As the rain and the snow come down from heaven, and do not return to it without watering the earth and making it bud and flourish ~ so is my word that goes out from my mouth: It will not return to Me empty, but will accomplish what I desire and achieve the purpose for which I sent it. (Isa. 55:10, 11)
reflection: A pastor who had shared God's Word finally gave up, because the person continually rejected him. Then weeks after giving up, his phone rang, it was the very same person asking to join the church. What he couldn't do, the Lord had done. The young pastor had learned a valuable lesson. His job was to share the Word; the Lord's job was to make it work in the human heart. Just as God decides where and when the snow will fall, so He determines where and when His Word will bring dead hearts to faith. If only we could see the Holy Spirit at work through that powerful Word, we would be more encouraged in our attempts to share it. Since we can't we need to remember this important truth: Our job is to share the snow, (word) not to make it grow. So let it snow! on your relatives, neighbors, friends, coworkers fellow students whoever. They need the life-giving message of their only Savior from sin and only deliverer from death. Into our hands God has placed His Word. In His hands rests the results He has promised.
prayer: Dear Lord, I ask Your blessing upon our sharing of Your powerful Word. Use it to bring dead hearts to life. And give us the patients to wait on the results. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Go into all the world and preach the good news to all creation. (Mk. 16:15)
reflection: Every hour on the hour, 365 days a year, a soldier reports for duty at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery. The precision of the changing of the guard is impressive. Even more impressive are the orders handed on. Always the command is the same, "Orders remain unchanged." Shouldn't we say the same about the command the risen Savior has given His soldiers of all times? "Go, " he charged, "into all the world." "Preach the good news, " He commanded, "to all creation." "And when you have done it, " He continued, "pass the order onto those who follow you." The orders of the day for believers are always the same, Not to guard a tomb in which an unknown body rests but to tell all creation of their living, loving Savior, their only Savior. So soldiers of the cross, how goes it? ~ Whom have you told? You say, "I can't reach very far." Well then, how about your family, your neighborhood, your small corner of the world?" "I can't do very much!" you excuse. Well then, how about your prayers and dollars for missions? We may never cross oceans to distant worlds. But we can build boats that carry those who go. and we can fish in lakes right in our own backyards.
prayer: Lord, here I am. Move me, use me, and bless my efforts to tell others about You. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
reflection: It seems that the thing most talked about for the coming year in fashions is, how long or short will the dresses be, what colors will be in, what about accessories? Will men's suits be double breasted, or have three buttons. Christians know something about proper dress. In fact, only Christians know about the right clothing for heaven. The garments of salvation are not union made but divinely tailored. They carry no dry-cleaning labels but are always pressed and spotless. They are not made for hanging in the closet but for everyday wear. And they are the only dress that gets us into heaven's party. At our baptism God clothed us with the garments of His salvation. By His grace, Christ's forgiveness covered us and His holiness counted for us. Through His Word, as we hear and read it, He wraps that beautiful robe more tightly around us and fastens its buttons more securely. When our final day comes, it will be His doing that we can step "clothed in His righteousness alone, faultless to stand before His throne."
prayer: Dear Lord Jesus, please let Your blood and righteousness by my beauty and my glorious dress. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: The One enthroned in heaven laughs; the Lord scoffs at them. (Ps. 2:4)
reflection: What's a person to do? The world in which we have to live and breath is becoming increasingly polluted. All around us ~ in movies and TV ~ in adds and commercials ~ and even within some churches, beats the appealing chant that man can have it all ~ do it all ~ ignore it all. SO what are we supposed to do??? Do we just shrug our shoulders and ask what else is new? ~ Do we just throw in the towel and surrender? Do we just say, thank God we have gray hair and won't see what our grandchildren will have to face??? Or should we join David in today's verse? He raised his face to heaven, and what he saw comforted him. The sinful efforts of the world aren't enough to make the One who sits on heaven's throne even leave His seat. Their feeble attempts to war against Him and His own are only enough to make Him laugh. The Almighty Ruler of all has never heard anything so humorous as man's empty boasting. He's never seen anything so funny as mankind's incompetent attempts to get along without Him. Yes we must all agree, times are evil. But we're not going to give up. Why should we? We're going to win! He who sits in the heavens is laughing, and we with Him. His Word still stands. His ways will still endure. And when the dust settles in the future as in the past, it will be victory that we shall see.
prayer: Almighty God, fix our faith on You so that we have comfort in the midst of life's turmoil. Amen.

Our Lesson for Today:
What's a person to do? The world in which we have to live and breath is
becoming increasingly polluted. All around us ~ in movies and TV ~ in adds
and commercials ~ and even within some churches, beats the appealing
chant that man can have it all ~ do it all ~ ignore it all. SO what are we supposed
to do???

Do we just shrug our shoulders and ask what else is new? ~ Do we just throw in 
the towel and surrender? Do we just say, thank God we have gray hair and won't
see what our grandchildren will have to face??? 

Or should we join David in today's verse? He raised his face to heaven, and what 
he saw comforted him. The sinful efforts of the world aren't enough to make the 
One who sits on heaven's throne even leave His seat...

Their feeble attempts to war against Him and His own are only enough to make Him
laugh. The Almighty Ruler of all has never heard anything so humorous as man's empty 
boasting. He's never seen anything so funny as mankind's incompetent attempts to 
get along without Him...

Yes we must all agree, times are evil. But we're not going to give up. Why should we?
We're going to win! He who sits in the heavens is laughing, and we with Him. His Word
still stands. His ways will still endure. And when the dust settles in the future as in the 
past, it will be victory that we shall see...

Prayer Suggestion:
Almighty God, fix our faith on You so that we have
comfort in the midst of life's turmoil...Amen.

Pastor Alvin & Marcie Sather

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Whatever you do, whether in word or deed, do it all in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the Father through Him. (Col. 3:17)
reflection: How ordinary life can seem. Day after day we get up, clean up, and hurry up, off to the duties of another day. Then we return home, have supper, clean up the kitchen, watch some TV, and head back to bed. But don't forget to set the alarm, because tomorrow it starts all over again. But for Christians it should never be just another day. Because each day the Lord gives us golden opportunities to serve Him ~ to show our appreciation for the eternal life that He has already given us. Just as a hot dog without mustard doesn't taste right, so life without Christ has no zip. But add the Savior and life takes on new meaning. The "just another day" becomes another day to serve Him in grateful love.
prayer: Dear Lord, take our moments and our days, let them flow in ceaseless praise. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: I am the bread of live. He who comes to Me will never go hungry. (Jn. 6:35)
reflection: Like our body, our soul needs bread or it will die. But unlike our bodies, stuff that looks like bread will not do the job. Some set before the hungry soul the loaves of man's own works. But such bread does not contain the vitamins of forgiveness. Others serve up the packaged loaves of man's own theology. But such bread is full of holes, holding no sure promise of an eternal home. Where do you find good bread? The hungry soul needs to know. In Jesus! When He described Himself as the bread of life, He had more than flour, shortening, and water in mind. He meant His perfect life that would fulfill all of God's commands and His precious blood that would be spilt in full payment for all sins. The soul, famished because of sin, can feast on Jesus' payment and be filled. The soul, hungry for a perfect life to present to God in the judgement, can reach for Jesus' righteousness and be satisfied. For the hungry sinner, Jesus is not just good bread. He is the only bread.
prayer: Dear Lord Jesus, help me to feast on You through my use of Your Word. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "How do you know me?" Nathaniel asked. Jesus answered, "I saw you while you were still under the fig tree before Philip called you." Then Nathanael declared, "Rabbi, You are the Son of God; You are the King of Israel." (Jn. 1:48, 49)
reflection: The two had never met before that day. Yet the One knew the other perfectly. Jesus knew Nathaniel's name and character, what he had been doing, and what he needed. Sound familiar??? Jesus knows us too. He knows the sudden sins that sweep down on us like a tornado. He knows the wreckage they leave on our conscience. and He knows the daily sins that are as close to us as our skin ~ that we don't always recognize as wrong. Like Nathanael, who was looking for the Savior to come, we need Jesus. And He knows this. So He speaks to us through His Word. He tells us that He forgives us because He's already paid for our sins. Like Nathanael, its time for us to say joyfully, and thankfully, "Jesus, You are the Son of God, my eternal King, my beloved Savior."
prayer: Thank You, Jesus, for being my Savior and for the heaven you have waiting for me. Amen

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "The time has come." He said."The kingdom of God is near. Repent and believe the Good News!" (Mk. 1:5)
reflection: What Jesus has to say can be summed up with four Rs. He tells us to realize that we have sinned ~ More times than we can count, more ways than we can remember. He tells us to regret that we have sinned ~ Not just to mouth the words "I'm sorry" but to hang our heads in shame before our Holy Father. Then He tells us to rely on His full forgiveness to cover those sins ~ To find in Him the pardon we need and the peace to stand before our loving Father again. Last of all, He tells us to resolve to fight against our sins ~ Not just take His pardon and run but to promise with His power to amend our sinful lives. Remember there is no shelf life on Jesus' message of repentance. What He has to say never goes out of date regardless of how many new years come. Sinners like you and me need to hear again and again His important words, "Repent and believe the Good News."
prayer: Dear Lord, open my ears to hear and my heart to receive Your Good News. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: With My authority take this message of repentance to all the nations, beginning in Jerusalem: 'There is forgiveness of sins for all people who turn to Me. ' You are My witnesses of all these things. (Lk. 24:47, 48)
reflection: As members of Christ's family, we have a responsibilities. Or perhaps we should call them privileges. They are efforts we should put forward in a willing, grateful response to what the Savior has done for our salvation. Of course, such actions cover our whole lives. We want everything in word and deed to be done to His glory. But one privilege stands out above all others. That's the work the risen Savior has given us ~ to be His witnesses. We who have seen His cross and empty tomb need to tell others. We need to share with the needy the Good News of the forgiveness of sins. On the job??? Perhaps we can't all become a pastor or a teacher. Perhaps we can't all fly to distant continents or move to expanding areas of our country. But we can still witness. We can tell the child on our lap, we can tell the neighbor down the street, we can tell a coworker on the job about the Jesus who loves them. We can speak our prayers and we can bring our offerings for the spreading of the gospel.
prayer: Dear Lord, move me, use me, bless me. Amen

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: On the third day a wedding took place at Cana in Galilee. Jesus' mother was there, and Jesus and His disciples were invited to the wedding. (Jn. 2:1, 2)
reflection: Did you know that Jesus' first recorded miracle was at a wedding celebration? He had just begun His ministry, just been baptized in the Jordan, just been tempted in the wilderness, just called His first disciples, when we find Him at a wedding reception? He was busy, as we can well imagine, but not to busy to accept the invitation of this bride and groom. As a friend he was there rejoicing with them and even increasing their joy with His miracle of changing water into wine. Dose this tell us something about the Christian? The world has it all wrong. Believers are not the gloomiest; they are the happiest people on earth. Who but the Christian can have real joy in this sin-muddied world? Only a life that is faith filled, and hope filled can be a joyous one. And such a joyous life is found in Christ, our heavenly Friend. When His forgiveness fills our lives and His love colors our days, smiles, not frowns, are in place. When our heavenly Friend stands beside us at our celebrations and in our daily lives, our smiles are heightened and our joys brightened.
prayer: Dear Lord, fill my heart with joy and my life with smiles through Your presence. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: This, the first of His miraculous signs, Jesus performed in Cana of Galilee. He thus revealed His glory, and His disciples put their faith in Him. (Jn. 2:11)
reflection: Far greater than the miracle of water turned into wine was the invisible miracle that day at the wedding. As always Jesus' miracles were not to make a grand display of Himself or dazzle those around Him. They were intended as signs to point sinners to Him for the greater needs of their souls. The miracles were powerful displays of His ability to rescue the people from sin, death, and the devil. Though many missed the point, His disciples at Cana that day didn't. Here is what we read of them, "His disciples put their faith in Him." See what this heavenly friend did for them. He strengthened their faith. He became closer and dearer to them, more precious and glorious than ever before. Do we want our faith and friendship with Jesus strengthened? There is a way, one that the world despises and that even some lukewarm friends of Jesus at times disregards. As we hear His Holy Word in our churches and read it at home, He sends His Spirit to renew our faith. As we receive the Lord's Supper at His altar, He refreshes our hearts. And through the miracle of Holy Baptism, He makes and then reminds us of His promise that we are His and He is ours forever.
prayer: Dear Lord, I invite You as a guest of my heart and home with Your straightening of my faith. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Whoever drinks the water I give him will never thirst. (Jn. 4:14)
reflection: Though many do not feel it or admit it, their souls beg for relief from the burning anguish of sin. In their ignorance and stubbornness, they turn to the world's wells. But like an alcoholic, the more they drink the less their thirst is quenched. Instead of labeling these wells as "unsafe for human consumption, " Satan disguises the spouts to deceive the thirsty traveler. But the time comes when the wells of power, possession, pleasure, and philosophy, where people have let down their buckets of an extravagant life style, will come to find that it is only poison for their soul. There is only one well that can quench the soul's thirst. Jesus said it clearly, "Whoever drinks the water I give Him will never thirst." With His atoning death on Calvary's holy mountain, He opened the pure and healing fountain that flows to you, to me, to all. Now He channels His thirst-quenching forgiveness to us through the riverbeds of the Word and sacraments. if all who lived on the earth were to come and drink, never could they drain His forgiveness dry.
prayer: Dear Lord, draw me to Your Word and lead me to drink deeply of the water of life You offer. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: They (the disciples) woke Him (Jesus), saying, "Lord, save us! We're going to drown!" (Mt. 8:25)
reflection: Are you having trouble falling asleep at night? An elderly gentlemen was asked how he could fall asleep so fast. His answer was "I just say my prayers to Jesus out loud and roller over and go to sleep. There is no use in both of us staying awake." This gentlemen had learned the secret of sleeping through the storms of life. The disciples had done everything they had learned to do as seamen but to no avail. their seaman skills did no good. They even were beginning to think that Jesus was no good as He slept, seemingly unconcerned. How wrong they were! He had come from heaven to rescue them from the hurricane of sin. He would go to the cross so that with nail-pierced hands He could invite sin-tossed souls, "Come to me, . and I will give you rest." (Mt. 11:28) When such loving, almighty hands are wrapped around the stomas of life, those who sail with God are safe. Perhaps the disciples didn't roll over and fall asleep the next time they ran into a storm out on the lake ~ BUT they trusted that their Jesus wasn't sleeping either. It's not that we should stop rowing, BUT that we should start trusting Jesus in the storms of life.
prayer: Dear Lord, help me to trust that there is pardon for all my sins, in the wounds of Your hands; AND that there is relief in Your hands from all of life's storms. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: He [Jesus] said, "I am the light of the world. Whoever follows Me will never walk in darkness, but will have the light of life." (Jn. 8:12)
reflection: Batteries are getting better all the time. But sooner or later they fail. But not so with Jesus. Like some all-powerful searchlight, He penetrates the dense midnight of sin, pushes aside the darkness of death, and points the way through earth's gloom to heaven. Not only does He light the way; He is the way. With His death and resurrection, He paid for sin and now stands like some well-lit ladder to heaven. With His redemptive work, He's the laser that beams us up to eternity. Jesus stands revealed in Scripture as the lasting light of salvation for all times.
prayer: Dear Lord Jesus, Light of the world, shine upon us, set us free by the truth you now bring us. Amen.
